revision.text:
{{Infobox military person | name =Alfred J. Whittle Jr. | image =ADM Whittle, Alfred James Jr.jpg | image_size= | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date|1924|2|23}} | death_date = {{Death date and age|1993|5|18|1924|2|23}} | birth_place = [[Mount Vernon, New York]] | death_place = [[Arlington, Virginia]] | placeofburial = | placeofburial_label = | placeofburial_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline,title}} --> | nickname = | birth_name = | allegiance = {{US}} | branch = [[United States Navy]] | serviceyears =1945–1981 | rank = [[Admiral (United States)|Admiral]] | servicenumber = | unit = | commands = [[Office of Naval Material]] | battles = | battles_label = | awards = | relations = | laterwork = | signature = }} '''Alfred James Whittle, Jr.''' (February 23, 1924 – May 18, 1993) was an [[Admiral (United States)|admiral]] in the [[United States Navy]].
Whittle graduated from the [[United States Naval Academy]] in June 1945. His first assignment was on {{USS|Harry E. Hubbard|DD-748}}. Transitioning to submarines, he commanded {{USS|Sterlet|SS-392}}, {{USS|Seawolf|SSN-575}} and {{USS|Andrew Jackson|SSBN-619}}. He was [[Office of Naval Material|Chief of Naval Material]] from 1978 to 1981. Awards and decorations he received include the [[Navy Distinguished Service Medal]], [[Legion of Merit]] and Meritorious Service Medal.
He died of cancer in 1993.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nytimes.com/1993/05/22/obituaries/alfred-whittle-69-admiral-built-career-around-submarines.html |title=Alfred Whittle, 69; Admiral Built Career Around Submarines |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=22 May 1993 |accessdate=2012-03-09}}</ref><ref> {{cite web |url=http://archives.rotor.com/documents/HFI%20DOCUMENTS/DOC102309-049.pdf |title=Biography Alfred J. Whittle, Jr. Admiral U. S. Navy |publisher=Helicopter Foundation International Historical Archive |format=pdf |accessdate=2012-09-14 }}</ref>
